newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sony posts record profit on robust sales, weak yen.
newsitem.headline: Sony posts record profit on robust sales, weak yen.

text.p: Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp on Thursday unveiled record group profits for the last business year, aided by robust global sales and a weak yen, and predicted further growth in the current year.

"Our group sales, operating profit and net profit during the 1996/97 business year all reached the highest levels in Sony's history," the company said in a statement. Parent sales and operating profit were also the highest on record.

Sony's group net profit was 139.46 billion yen ($1.12 billion) in the year to March, up 2.6-fold from the year before. Parent current profit was 85.73 billion yen ($691 million), a three-fold increase from the previous year.
Net profit is equal to current profit, which is pre-tax, minus taxes and extraordinary profits and losses.

The strong earnings result, which came after the Tokyo stock market closed, may not be a great surprise to the market, which already pushed Sony's shares briefly to a record high of 9,800 yen on Thursday. The shares ended at 9,720 yen in Tokyo, up 90 yen from Wednesday's close.
"Larger group sales were due to higher sales in Japan, the United States, Europe and other areas as well as the yen's depreciation," Sony said in the statement.
In 1996/97 the yen fell about 15 percent against the dollar and weakened against other foreign currencies as well.
Sony said the yen's fall against other major currencies, which makes Japanese exports more competitive abroad, raised its 1996/97 group sales by about 520 billion yen ($4.19 billion).
Sony said that sales rose in all its business areas including electronics, entertainment, insurance and financing.
Sales of the company's cutting-edge 32-bit home game player, the PlayStation, contributed to a 24.3 percent group in its group revenue in the electronics sector.
In the entertainment sector, group operating revenue grew 23.1 percent to 1.02 trillion yen ($8.2 billion) in 1996/97.
Sony's entertainment revenues come largely from its troubled Hollywood film-making unit, Sony Pictures Entertainment, and its recording unit, Sony Music Entertainment.
"Sales in the music group continued to rise despite the weak retail environment in the United States, primarily due to favourable sales growth outside Japan," Sony said.
One notable success was Canadian pop diva Celine Dion's "Falling Into You," which has sold more than 21 million copies since its March 1996 release, it said.
Sales in the pictures group rose significantly, aided by continued strength in television operations and the success of videos such as "Jumanji" and "Matilda."
The blockbuster romantic comedy "Jerry Maguire," which has grossed $150 million at the U.S. box office, also contributed to the year's favourable results, Sony said.
"All of those positive factors, in addition to the yen's depreciation, more than offset the disappointing box office results of several films released during the year," it said.
Sony said that it expected group net profit to grow further to 160 billion yen ($1.29 billion) and parent current profit to increase to 100 billion yen ($806 million) in 1997/98. (1$=124 yen)
